@@ -0,0 +1,155 @@ +# Troubleshooting performance issues + +Performance is at the heart of Quarkus. + +If you are facing performance issues (runtime or startup issues), and would like to discuss them with the Quarkus Team, +you are more than welcome on our [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/d/forum/quarkus-dev), +[Zulip chat](https://quarkusio.zulipchat.com) or [Github issue tracker](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues). + +To help us to troubleshoot your issues, we will need some performance insight from your application. + +On Linux or macOS, one of the best way to gather performance insight would be to generate CPU and allocation [FlameGraphs](https://github.com/brendangregg/FlameGraph) +via [Async Profiler](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler). + +If you want a deeper introduction to Async Profiler, go read [this article](https://hackernoon.com/profiling-java-applications-with-async-profiler-049s2790). + +## Installing Async Profiler + +To install Async Profiler, go to the [release page](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/releases) and download the latest release. + +Async Profiler depends on `perf_events`.
+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`:

@@ -0,0 +1,155 @@
+# Troubleshooting performance issues
+
+Performance is at the heart of Quarkus.
+
+If you are facing performance issues (runtime or startup issues), and would like to discuss them with the Quarkus Team,
+you are more than welcome on our [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/d/forum/quarkus-dev),
+[Zulip chat](https://quarkusio.zulipchat.com) or [Github issue tracker](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues).
+
+To help us to troubleshoot your issues, we will need some performance insight from your application.
+
+On Linux or macOS, one of the best way to gather performance insight would be to generate CPU and allocation [FlameGraphs](https://github.com/brendangregg/FlameGraph) 
+via [Async Profiler](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler).
+
+If you want a deeper introduction to Async Profiler, go read [this article](https://hackernoon.com/profiling-java-applications-with-async-profiler-049s2790).

@@ -0,0 +1,155 @@ +# Troubleshooting performance issues + +Performance is at the heart of Quarkus. + +If you are facing performance issues (runtime or startup issues), and would like to discuss them with the Quarkus Team, +you are more than welcome on our [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/d/forum/quarkus-dev), +[Zulip chat](https://quarkusio.zulipchat.com) or [Github issue tracker](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues). + +To help us to troubleshoot your issues, we will need some performance insight from your application. + +On Linux or macOS, one of the best way to gather performance insight would be to generate CPU and allocation [FlameGraphs](https://github.com/brendangregg/FlameGraph) +via [Async Profiler](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler). + +If you want a deeper introduction to Async Profiler, go read [this article](https://hackernoon.com/profiling-java-applications-with-async-profiler-049s2790). + +## Installing Async Profiler + +To install Async Profiler, go to the [release page](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/releases) and download the latest release. + +Async Profiler depends on `perf_events`.
+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration.

@@ -0,0 +1,155 @@ +# Troubleshooting performance issues + +Performance is at the heart of Quarkus. + +If you are facing performance issues (runtime or startup issues), and would like to discuss them with the Quarkus Team, +you are more than welcome on our [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/d/forum/quarkus-dev), +[Zulip chat](https://quarkusio.zulipchat.com) or [Github issue tracker](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues). + +To help us to troubleshoot your issues, we will need some performance insight from your application. + +On Linux or macOS, one of the best way to gather performance insight would be to generate CPU and allocation [FlameGraphs](https://github.com/brendangregg/FlameGraph) +via [Async Profiler](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler). + +If you want a deeper introduction to Async Profiler, go read [this article](https://hackernoon.com/profiling-java-applications-with-async-profiler-049s2790). + +## Installing Async Profiler + +To install Async Profiler, go to the [release page](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/releases) and download the latest release. + +Async Profiler depends on `perf_events`.
+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling).

This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters Suggested change Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
This can be important as any application performs a lot of bootstrapping operation upon startup that won't occur at any other during the application lifecycle.

@@ -0,0 +1,155 @@ +# Troubleshooting performance issues + +Performance is at the heart of Quarkus. + +If you are facing performance issues (runtime or startup issues), and would like to discuss them with the Quarkus Team, +you are more than welcome on our [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/d/forum/quarkus-dev), +[Zulip chat](https://quarkusio.zulipchat.com) or [Github issue tracker](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues). + +To help us to troubleshoot your issues, we will need some performance insight from your application. + +On Linux or macOS, one of the best way to gather performance insight would be to generate CPU and allocation [FlameGraphs](https://github.com/brendangregg/FlameGraph) +via [Async Profiler](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler). + +If you want a deeper introduction to Async Profiler, go read [this article](https://hackernoon.com/profiling-java-applications-with-async-profiler-049s2790). + +## Installing Async Profiler + +To install Async Profiler, go to the [release page](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/releases) and download the latest release. + +Async Profiler depends on `perf_events`.
+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.

@@ -0,0 +1,155 @@ +# Troubleshooting performance issues + +Performance is at the heart of Quarkus. + +If you are facing performance issues (runtime or startup issues), and would like to discuss them with the Quarkus Team, +you are more than welcome on our [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/d/forum/quarkus-dev), +[Zulip chat](https://quarkusio.zulipchat.com) or [Github issue tracker](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues). + +To help us to troubleshoot your issues, we will need some performance insight from your application. + +On Linux or macOS, one of the best way to gather performance insight would be to generate CPU and allocation [FlameGraphs](https://github.com/brendangregg/FlameGraph) +via [Async Profiler](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler). + +If you want a deeper introduction to Async Profiler, go read [this article](https://hackernoon.com/profiling-java-applications-with-async-profiler-049s2790). + +## Installing Async Profiler + +To install Async Profiler, go to the [release page](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/releases) and download the latest release. + +Async Profiler depends on `perf_events`.
+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile.

nodes.bodyText:
I can remove ab from the list.
As I previously said, load testing is a vast and debatable subject.
There is multiple type of tools (URL basher, scenario based load testing, ...), some are paid some are free, some uses complex injectors, ...
And using these tools is far from easy ...
I added these ones because these are the one I'm used to, but any will works to generates a profile (not any will works to simulate correctly user interaction).
I'm open to suggestion here, we can add a section about them or create a dedicated page for them later.
We also have the performance page where we can add some section to tools used to generate load: https://quarkus.io/guides/performance-measure
Maybe we need to link this page inside the performance page ?

+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...),

+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...), +and to start profiling only after some warmup time to allow the Just In Time compiler of Java to optimize your application code (and your database cache to warmup, etc...).

+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...), +and to start profiling only after some warmup time to allow the Just In Time compiler of Java to optimize your application code (and your database cache to warmup, etc...). + +### CPU profiling + +To start CPU profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 +``` + +`-b 4000000` is used to increase the frame buffer size as the default is usually too small.

+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...), +and to start profiling only after some warmup time to allow the Just In Time compiler of Java to optimize your application code (and your database cache to warmup, etc...). + +### CPU profiling + +To start CPU profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 +``` + +`-b 4000000` is used to increase the frame buffer size as the default is usually too small. + +To end profiling and gathering the result you can launch the same command with the `stop` subcommand, this will tells you if the buffer frame was too small.

+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...), +and to start profiling only after some warmup time to allow the Just In Time compiler of Java to optimize your application code (and your database cache to warmup, etc...). + +### CPU profiling + +To start CPU profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 +``` + +`-b 4000000` is used to increase the frame buffer size as the default is usually too small. + +To end profiling and gathering the result you can launch the same command with the `stop` subcommand, this will tells you if the buffer frame was too small.
+The output is a text file that is not really usable, so let's use our preferred performance representation: The FlameGraph. + +```shell script +./profiler.sh stop -f /tmp/cpu-profile.svg --width 1600 +``` + +It will create an SVG FlameGraph (Async Profiler automatically detect that you ask for a FlameGraph thanks to the svg extension)

@@ -0,0 +1,155 @@ +# Troubleshooting performance issues + +Performance is at the heart of Quarkus. + +If you are facing performance issues (runtime or startup issues), and would like to discuss them with the Quarkus Team, +you are more than welcome on our [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/d/forum/quarkus-dev), +[Zulip chat](https://quarkusio.zulipchat.com) or [Github issue tracker](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues). + +To help us to troubleshoot your issues, we will need some performance insight from your application. + +On Linux or macOS, one of the best way to gather performance insight would be to generate CPU and allocation [FlameGraphs](https://github.com/brendangregg/FlameGraph) +via [Async Profiler](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler). + +If you want a deeper introduction to Async Profiler, go read [this article](https://hackernoon.com/profiling-java-applications-with-async-profiler-049s2790). + +## Installing Async Profiler + +To install Async Profiler, go to the [release page](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/releases) and download the latest release. + +Async Profiler depends on `perf_events`.
+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...), +and to start profiling only after some warmup time to allow the Just In Time compiler of Java to optimize your application code (and your database cache to warmup, etc...). + +### CPU profiling + +To start CPU profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 +``` + +`-b 4000000` is used to increase the frame buffer size as the default is usually too small. + +To end profiling and gathering the result you can launch the same command with the `stop` subcommand, this will tells you if the buffer frame was too small.
+The output is a text file that is not really usable, so let's use our preferred performance representation: The FlameGraph. + +```shell script +./profiler.sh stop -f /tmp/cpu-profile.svg --width 1600 +``` + +It will create an SVG FlameGraph (Async Profiler automatically detect that you ask for a FlameGraph thanks to the svg extension)

+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...), +and to start profiling only after some warmup time to allow the Just In Time compiler of Java to optimize your application code (and your database cache to warmup, etc...). + +### CPU profiling + +To start CPU profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 +``` + +`-b 4000000` is used to increase the frame buffer size as the default is usually too small. + +To end profiling and gathering the result you can launch the same command with the `stop` subcommand, this will tells you if the buffer frame was too small.

+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...), +and to start profiling only after some warmup time to allow the Just In Time compiler of Java to optimize your application code (and your database cache to warmup, etc...). + +### CPU profiling + +To start CPU profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 +``` + +`-b 4000000` is used to increase the frame buffer size as the default is usually too small. + +To end profiling and gathering the result you can launch the same command with the `stop` subcommand, this will tells you if the buffer frame was too small.

+The output is a text file that is not really usable, so let's use our preferred performance representation: The FlameGraph. + +```shell script +./profiler.sh stop -f /tmp/cpu-profile.svg --width 1600 +``` + +It will create an SVG FlameGraph (Async Profiler automatically detect that you ask for a FlameGraph thanks to the svg extension) +that you can open in your browser (and even zoom inside it by clicking on a frame).
+The example command will create an SVG of 1600 pixels width. + +One of our favorite options is `-s` (or `--simple`) that use simple class names instead of FQDNs, the FlameGraph will be more readable with it, but you will lose the package name.
+You can also limit the profiling duration by using `-d` (or `--duration`) follow by the duration in seconds. + +### Allocation profiling + +To start allocation profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 -e alloc +``` + +`-e` (or `--event`) allow to give the event to profile, by default it's CPU, here we want allocation profiling.

+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...), +and to start profiling only after some warmup time to allow the Just In Time compiler of Java to optimize your application code (and your database cache to warmup, etc...). + +### CPU profiling + +To start CPU profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 +``` + +`-b 4000000` is used to increase the frame buffer size as the default is usually too small. + +To end profiling and gathering the result you can launch the same command with the `stop` subcommand, this will tells you if the buffer frame was too small.
+The output is a text file that is not really usable, so let's use our preferred performance representation: The FlameGraph. + +```shell script +./profiler.sh stop -f /tmp/cpu-profile.svg --width 1600 +``` + +It will create an SVG FlameGraph (Async Profiler automatically detect that you ask for a FlameGraph thanks to the svg extension) +that you can open in your browser (and even zoom inside it by clicking on a frame).
+The example command will create an SVG of 1600 pixels width. + +One of our favorite options is `-s` (or `--simple`) that use simple class names instead of FQDNs, the FlameGraph will be more readable with it, but you will lose the package name.
+You can also limit the profiling duration by using `-d` (or `--duration`) follow by the duration in seconds. + +### Allocation profiling + +To start allocation profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 -e alloc +``` + +`-e` (or `--event`) allow to give the event to profile, by default it's CPU, here we want allocation profiling. + +Then you can stop your profiling the same way as for CPU profiling. + +```shell script +./profiler.sh stop -f /tmp/alloc-profile.svg --width 1600 +``` + +## Profiling application startup with Async Profiler + +When you want to profile application startup, you cannot use the command line tool as you need a way to start the profiler with your application. + +For this case, the Java agent is the best tool. +It will start profiling when you start the application, then record the profiling data when the application exits. + +Here is some example command lines:

@@ -0,0 +1,155 @@ +# Troubleshooting performance issues + +Performance is at the heart of Quarkus. + +If you are facing performance issues (runtime or startup issues), and would like to discuss them with the Quarkus Team, +you are more than welcome on our [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/d/forum/quarkus-dev), +[Zulip chat](https://quarkusio.zulipchat.com) or [Github issue tracker](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues). + +To help us to troubleshoot your issues, we will need some performance insight from your application. + +On Linux or macOS, one of the best way to gather performance insight would be to generate CPU and allocation [FlameGraphs](https://github.com/brendangregg/FlameGraph) +via [Async Profiler](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler). + +If you want a deeper introduction to Async Profiler, go read [this article](https://hackernoon.com/profiling-java-applications-with-async-profiler-049s2790). + +## Installing Async Profiler + +To install Async Profiler, go to the [release page](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/releases) and download the latest release. + +Async Profiler depends on `perf_events`.
+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...), +and to start profiling only after some warmup time to allow the Just In Time compiler of Java to optimize your application code (and your database cache to warmup, etc...). + +### CPU profiling + +To start CPU profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 +``` + +`-b 4000000` is used to increase the frame buffer size as the default is usually too small. + +To end profiling and gathering the result you can launch the same command with the `stop` subcommand, this will tells you if the buffer frame was too small.
+The output is a text file that is not really usable, so let's use our preferred performance representation: The FlameGraph. + +```shell script +./profiler.sh stop -f /tmp/cpu-profile.svg --width 1600 +``` + +It will create an SVG FlameGraph (Async Profiler automatically detect that you ask for a FlameGraph thanks to the svg extension) +that you can open in your browser (and even zoom inside it by clicking on a frame).
+The example command will create an SVG of 1600 pixels width. + +One of our favorite options is `-s` (or `--simple`) that use simple class names instead of FQDNs, the FlameGraph will be more readable with it, but you will lose the package name.
+You can also limit the profiling duration by using `-d` (or `--duration`) follow by the duration in seconds. + +### Allocation profiling + +To start allocation profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 -e alloc +``` + +`-e` (or `--event`) allow to give the event to profile, by default it's CPU, here we want allocation profiling. + +Then you can stop your profiling the same way as for CPU profiling. + +```shell script +./profiler.sh stop -f /tmp/alloc-profile.svg --width 1600 +``` + +## Profiling application startup with Async Profiler + +When you want to profile application startup, you cannot use the command line tool as you need a way to start the profiler with your application. + +For this case, the Java agent is the best tool. +It will start profiling when you start the application, then record the profiling data when the application exits. + +Here is some example command lines: + +```shell script +# profile CPU startup +java -agentpath:/path/to/async-profiler/build/libasyncProfiler.so=start,event=cpu,file=startup-cpu-profile.svg,interval=1000000,width=1600,simple\ + -jar my-application.jar + +# profile allocation startup +java -agentpath:/path/to/async-profiler/build/libasyncProfiler.so=start,event=alloc,file=/tmp/startup-alloc-profile.svg,interval=1000000,width=1600,simple\ + -jar my-application.jar +``` + +Be careful that short options are not supported inside the agent, you need to use the long version.

@@ -0,0 +1,155 @@ +# Troubleshooting performance issues + +Performance is at the heart of Quarkus. + +If you are facing performance issues (runtime or startup issues), and would like to discuss them with the Quarkus Team, +you are more than welcome on our [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/d/forum/quarkus-dev), +[Zulip chat](https://quarkusio.zulipchat.com) or [Github issue tracker](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues). + +To help us to troubleshoot your issues, we will need some performance insight from your application. + +On Linux or macOS, one of the best way to gather performance insight would be to generate CPU and allocation [FlameGraphs](https://github.com/brendangregg/FlameGraph) +via [Async Profiler](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler). + +If you want a deeper introduction to Async Profiler, go read [this article](https://hackernoon.com/profiling-java-applications-with-async-profiler-049s2790). + +## Installing Async Profiler + +To install Async Profiler, go to the [release page](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/releases) and download the latest release. + +Async Profiler depends on `perf_events`.
+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...), +and to start profiling only after some warmup time to allow the Just In Time compiler of Java to optimize your application code (and your database cache to warmup, etc...). + +### CPU profiling + +To start CPU profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 +``` + +`-b 4000000` is used to increase the frame buffer size as the default is usually too small. + +To end profiling and gathering the result you can launch the same command with the `stop` subcommand, this will tells you if the buffer frame was too small.
+The output is a text file that is not really usable, so let's use our preferred performance representation: The FlameGraph. + +```shell script +./profiler.sh stop -f /tmp/cpu-profile.svg --width 1600 +``` + +It will create an SVG FlameGraph (Async Profiler automatically detect that you ask for a FlameGraph thanks to the svg extension) +that you can open in your browser (and even zoom inside it by clicking on a frame).
+The example command will create an SVG of 1600 pixels width. + +One of our favorite options is `-s` (or `--simple`) that use simple class names instead of FQDNs, the FlameGraph will be more readable with it, but you will lose the package name.
+You can also limit the profiling duration by using `-d` (or `--duration`) follow by the duration in seconds. + +### Allocation profiling + +To start allocation profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 -e alloc +``` + +`-e` (or `--event`) allow to give the event to profile, by default it's CPU, here we want allocation profiling. + +Then you can stop your profiling the same way as for CPU profiling. + +```shell script +./profiler.sh stop -f /tmp/alloc-profile.svg --width 1600 +``` + +## Profiling application startup with Async Profiler + +When you want to profile application startup, you cannot use the command line tool as you need a way to start the profiler with your application. + +For this case, the Java agent is the best tool. +It will start profiling when you start the application, then record the profiling data when the application exits. + +Here is some example command lines: + +```shell script +# profile CPU startup +java -agentpath:/path/to/async-profiler/build/libasyncProfiler.so=start,event=cpu,file=startup-cpu-profile.svg,interval=1000000,width=1600,simple\ + -jar my-application.jar + +# profile allocation startup +java -agentpath:/path/to/async-profiler/build/libasyncProfiler.so=start,event=alloc,file=/tmp/startup-alloc-profile.svg,interval=1000000,width=1600,simple\ + -jar my-application.jar +``` + +Be careful that short options are not supported inside the agent, you need to use the long version. + +By default, Async Profiler sample events each 10ms, for debugging Quarkus startup issue this is too much as we start very fast ;)
+That's why I configure the profiling interval to 1000000ns (so 1ms).

@@ -0,0 +1,155 @@ +# Troubleshooting performance issues + +Performance is at the heart of Quarkus. + +If you are facing performance issues (runtime or startup issues), and would like to discuss them with the Quarkus Team, +you are more than welcome on our [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/d/forum/quarkus-dev), +[Zulip chat](https://quarkusio.zulipchat.com) or [Github issue tracker](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues). + +To help us to troubleshoot your issues, we will need some performance insight from your application. + +On Linux or macOS, one of the best way to gather performance insight would be to generate CPU and allocation [FlameGraphs](https://github.com/brendangregg/FlameGraph) +via [Async Profiler](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler). + +If you want a deeper introduction to Async Profiler, go read [this article](https://hackernoon.com/profiling-java-applications-with-async-profiler-049s2790). + +## Installing Async Profiler + +To install Async Profiler, go to the [release page](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/releases) and download the latest release. + +Async Profiler depends on `perf_events`.
+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...), +and to start profiling only after some warmup time to allow the Just In Time compiler of Java to optimize your application code (and your database cache to warmup, etc...). + +### CPU profiling + +To start CPU profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 +``` + +`-b 4000000` is used to increase the frame buffer size as the default is usually too small. + +To end profiling and gathering the result you can launch the same command with the `stop` subcommand, this will tells you if the buffer frame was too small.
+The output is a text file that is not really usable, so let's use our preferred performance representation: The FlameGraph.

@@ -0,0 +1,155 @@ +# Troubleshooting performance issues + +Performance is at the heart of Quarkus. + +If you are facing performance issues (runtime or startup issues), and would like to discuss them with the Quarkus Team, +you are more than welcome on our [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/d/forum/quarkus-dev), +[Zulip chat](https://quarkusio.zulipchat.com) or [Github issue tracker](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues). + +To help us to troubleshoot your issues, we will need some performance insight from your application. + +On Linux or macOS, one of the best way to gather performance insight would be to generate CPU and allocation [FlameGraphs](https://github.com/brendangregg/FlameGraph) +via [Async Profiler](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler). + +If you want a deeper introduction to Async Profiler, go read [this article](https://hackernoon.com/profiling-java-applications-with-async-profiler-049s2790). + +## Installing Async Profiler + +To install Async Profiler, go to the [release page](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/releases) and download the latest release. + +Async Profiler depends on `perf_events`.
+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...), +and to start profiling only after some warmup time to allow the Just In Time compiler of Java to optimize your application code (and your database cache to warmup, etc...). + +### CPU profiling + +To start CPU profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 +``` + +`-b 4000000` is used to increase the frame buffer size as the default is usually too small. + +To end profiling and gathering the result you can launch the same command with the `stop` subcommand, this will tells you if the buffer frame was too small.
+The output is a text file that is not really usable, so let's use our preferred performance representation: The FlameGraph. + +```shell script +./profiler.sh stop -f /tmp/cpu-profile.svg --width 1600 +``` + +It will create an SVG FlameGraph (Async Profiler automatically detect that you ask for a FlameGraph thanks to the svg extension) +that you can open in your browser (and even zoom inside it by clicking on a frame).
+The example command will create an SVG of 1600 pixels width. + +One of our favorite options is `-s` (or `--simple`) that use simple class names instead of FQDNs, the FlameGraph will be more readable with it, but you will lose the package name.
+You can also limit the profiling duration by using `-d` (or `--duration`) follow by the duration in seconds.

@@ -0,0 +1,155 @@ +# Troubleshooting performance issues + +Performance is at the heart of Quarkus. + +If you are facing performance issues (runtime or startup issues), and would like to discuss them with the Quarkus Team, +you are more than welcome on our [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/d/forum/quarkus-dev), +[Zulip chat](https://quarkusio.zulipchat.com) or [Github issue tracker](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues). + +To help us to troubleshoot your issues, we will need some performance insight from your application. + +On Linux or macOS, one of the best way to gather performance insight would be to generate CPU and allocation [FlameGraphs](https://github.com/brendangregg/FlameGraph) +via [Async Profiler](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler). + +If you want a deeper introduction to Async Profiler, go read [this article](https://hackernoon.com/profiling-java-applications-with-async-profiler-049s2790). + +## Installing Async Profiler + +To install Async Profiler, go to the [release page](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/releases) and download the latest release. + +Async Profiler depends on `perf_events`.
+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...), +and to start profiling only after some warmup time to allow the Just In Time compiler of Java to optimize your application code (and your database cache to warmup, etc...). + +### CPU profiling + +To start CPU profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 +``` + +`-b 4000000` is used to increase the frame buffer size as the default is usually too small. + +To end profiling and gathering the result you can launch the same command with the `stop` subcommand, this will tells you if the buffer frame was too small.
+The output is a text file that is not really usable, so let's use our preferred performance representation: The FlameGraph. + +```shell script +./profiler.sh stop -f /tmp/cpu-profile.svg --width 1600 +``` + +It will create an SVG FlameGraph (Async Profiler automatically detect that you ask for a FlameGraph thanks to the svg extension) +that you can open in your browser (and even zoom inside it by clicking on a frame).
+The example command will create an SVG of 1600 pixels width. + +One of our favorite options is `-s` (or `--simple`) that use simple class names instead of FQDNs, the FlameGraph will be more readable with it, but you will lose the package name.
+You can also limit the profiling duration by using `-d` (or `--duration`) follow by the duration in seconds. + +### Allocation profiling + +To start allocation profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 -e alloc +``` + +`-e` (or `--event`) allow to give the event to profile, by default it's CPU, here we want allocation profiling. + +Then you can stop your profiling the same way as for CPU profiling. + +```shell script +./profiler.sh stop -f /tmp/alloc-profile.svg --width 1600 +``` + +## Profiling application startup with Async Profiler + +When you want to profile application startup, you cannot use the command line tool as you need a way to start the profiler with your application. + +For this case, the Java agent is the best tool. +It will start profiling when you start the application, then record the profiling data when the application exits. + +Here is some example command lines: + +```shell script +# profile CPU startup +java -agentpath:/path/to/async-profiler/build/libasyncProfiler.so=start,event=cpu,file=startup-cpu-profile.svg,interval=1000000,width=1600,simple\ + -jar my-application.jar + +# profile allocation startup +java -agentpath:/path/to/async-profiler/build/libasyncProfiler.so=start,event=alloc,file=/tmp/startup-alloc-profile.svg,interval=1000000,width=1600,simple\ + -jar my-application.jar +``` + +Be careful that short options are not supported inside the agent, you need to use the long version. + +By default, Async Profiler sample events each 10ms, for debugging Quarkus startup issue this is too much as we start very fast ;)
+That's why I configure the profiling interval to 1000000ns (so 1ms). + +## Profiling application dev mode with Async Profiler + +For profiling Quarkus dev mode, you also need to use the Java agent, you can use it the same way as for production run, but you need to pass the `agentpath` option inside the `jvm.args` system property. + +```shell script +# profile CPU startup +mvn quarkus:dev -Djvm.args="agentpath:/path/to/async-profiler/build/libasyncProfiler.so=start,event=cpu,file=startup-cpu-profile.svg,interval=1000000,width=1600,simple" + +# profile allocation startup +mvn quarkus:dev -Djvm.args="-agentpath:/path/to/async-profiler/build/libasyncProfiler.so=start,event=alloc,file=/tmp/startup-alloc-profile.svg,interval=1000000,width=1600,simple" +``` + +You can also configure the `jvm.args` system property directly inside the `quarkus-maven-plugin` configuration inside your pom.xml.

@@ -0,0 +1,155 @@ +# Troubleshooting performance issues + +Performance is at the heart of Quarkus. + +If you are facing performance issues (runtime or startup issues), and would like to discuss them with the Quarkus Team, +you are more than welcome on our [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/d/forum/quarkus-dev), +[Zulip chat](https://quarkusio.zulipchat.com) or [Github issue tracker](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues). + +To help us to troubleshoot your issues, we will need some performance insight from your application. + +On Linux or macOS, one of the best way to gather performance insight would be to generate CPU and allocation [FlameGraphs](https://github.com/brendangregg/FlameGraph) +via [Async Profiler](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler). + +If you want a deeper introduction to Async Profiler, go read [this article](https://hackernoon.com/profiling-java-applications-with-async-profiler-049s2790). + +## Installing Async Profiler + +To install Async Profiler, go to the [release page](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/releases) and download the latest release. + +Async Profiler depends on `perf_events`.
+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...), +and to start profiling only after some warmup time to allow the Just In Time compiler of Java to optimize your application code (and your database cache to warmup, etc...). + +### CPU profiling + +To start CPU profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 +``` + +`-b 4000000` is used to increase the frame buffer size as the default is usually too small. + +To end profiling and gathering the result you can launch the same command with the `stop` subcommand, this will tells you if the buffer frame was too small.
+The output is a text file that is not really usable, so let's use our preferred performance representation: The FlameGraph. + +```shell script +./profiler.sh stop -f /tmp/cpu-profile.svg --width 1600 +``` + +It will create an SVG FlameGraph (Async Profiler automatically detect that you ask for a FlameGraph thanks to the svg extension) +that you can open in your browser (and even zoom inside it by clicking on a frame).
+The example command will create an SVG of 1600 pixels width. + +One of our favorite options is `-s` (or `--simple`) that use simple class names instead of FQDNs, the FlameGraph will be more readable with it, but you will lose the package name.
+You can also limit the profiling duration by using `-d` (or `--duration`) follow by the duration in seconds. + +### Allocation profiling + +To start allocation profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 -e alloc +``` + +`-e` (or `--event`) allow to give the event to profile, by default it's CPU, here we want allocation profiling. + +Then you can stop your profiling the same way as for CPU profiling. + +```shell script +./profiler.sh stop -f /tmp/alloc-profile.svg --width 1600 +``` + +## Profiling application startup with Async Profiler + +When you want to profile application startup, you cannot use the command line tool as you need a way to start the profiler with your application. + +For this case, the Java agent is the best tool. +It will start profiling when you start the application, then record the profiling data when the application exits. + +Here is some example command lines: + +```shell script +# profile CPU startup +java -agentpath:/path/to/async-profiler/build/libasyncProfiler.so=start,event=cpu,file=startup-cpu-profile.svg,interval=1000000,width=1600,simple\ + -jar my-application.jar + +# profile allocation startup +java -agentpath:/path/to/async-profiler/build/libasyncProfiler.so=start,event=alloc,file=/tmp/startup-alloc-profile.svg,interval=1000000,width=1600,simple\ + -jar my-application.jar +``` + +Be careful that short options are not supported inside the agent, you need to use the long version. + +By default, Async Profiler sample events each 10ms, for debugging Quarkus startup issue this is too much as we start very fast ;)
+That's why I configure the profiling interval to 1000000ns (so 1ms). + +## Profiling application dev mode with Async Profiler + +For profiling Quarkus dev mode, you also need to use the Java agent, you can use it the same way as for production run, but you need to pass the `agentpath` option inside the `jvm.args` system property. + +```shell script +# profile CPU startup +mvn quarkus:dev -Djvm.args="agentpath:/path/to/async-profiler/build/libasyncProfiler.so=start,event=cpu,file=startup-cpu-profile.svg,interval=1000000,width=1600,simple" + +# profile allocation startup +mvn quarkus:dev -Djvm.args="-agentpath:/path/to/async-profiler/build/libasyncProfiler.so=start,event=alloc,file=/tmp/startup-alloc-profile.svg,interval=1000000,width=1600,simple" +``` + +You can also configure the `jvm.args` system property directly inside the `quarkus-maven-plugin` configuration inside your pom.xml. + +## And what about Windows ?

@@ -0,0 +1,155 @@ +# Troubleshooting performance issues + +Performance is at the heart of Quarkus. + +If you are facing performance issues (runtime or startup issues), and would like to discuss them with the Quarkus Team, +you are more than welcome on our [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/d/forum/quarkus-dev), +[Zulip chat](https://quarkusio.zulipchat.com) or [Github issue tracker](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues). + +To help us to troubleshoot your issues, we will need some performance insight from your application. + +On Linux or macOS, one of the best way to gather performance insight would be to generate CPU and allocation [FlameGraphs](https://github.com/brendangregg/FlameGraph) +via [Async Profiler](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler). + +If you want a deeper introduction to Async Profiler, go read [this article](https://hackernoon.com/profiling-java-applications-with-async-profiler-049s2790). + +## Installing Async Profiler + +To install Async Profiler, go to the [release page](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/releases) and download the latest release. + +Async Profiler depends on `perf_events`.
+To allow capturing kernel call stacks using `perf_events` from a non-root process, +you must make some OS configuration. + +For your session: + +```shell script +echo 1 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid +echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/kptr_restrict +``` + +Or definitively using `sysctl`: + +```shell script +sudo sysctl -w kernel.perf_event_paranoid=1 +sudo sysctl -w kernel.kptr_restrict=0 +``` + +For allocation profiling, you also need to install HotStop debug symbol. + +Depending on your Linux and Java distribution this can be done via: + +```shell script +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 8 +apt install openjdk-8-dbg + +# Ubuntu/Debian - Java 11 + apt install openjdk-11-dbg + +# On CentOS, RHEL and some other RPM-based distributions +debuginfo-install java-1.8.0-openjdk +``` + +If needed, see this section in the documentation site for details: [allocation profiling](https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#allocation-profiling). + +## Profiling application runtime with Async Profiler + +Asych Profiler comes with a Java agent, and a command line. + +To profile application during its runtime, I recommend using the command line as you can choose when to start the profiler, and avoid your profile to be bloated with startup events.
+Indeed, when an application start, it does a lot a bootstraping instruction, that will no more occur during the rest of the run of your application.
+By starting the profiling when needed, you avoid these bootstrap instructions to be part of the profile. + +When you profile an application runtime, it's good to create some load on your application using a load generator tool (wrk, gatling, ...), +and to start profiling only after some warmup time to allow the Just In Time compiler of Java to optimize your application code (and your database cache to warmup, etc...). + +### CPU profiling + +To start CPU profiling, enter the following command: + +```shell script +./profiler.sh start -b 4000000 +``` + +`-b 4000000` is used to increase the frame buffer size as the default is usually too small. + +To end profiling and gathering the result you can launch the same command with the `stop` subcommand, this will tells you if the buffer frame was too small.
+The output is a text file that is not really usable, so let's use our preferred performance representation: The FlameGraph. + +```shell script +./profiler.sh stop -f /tmp/cpu-profile.svg --width 1600 +``` + +It will create an SVG FlameGraph (Async Profiler automatically detect that you ask for a FlameGraph thanks to the svg extension) +that you can open in your browser (and even zoom inside it by clicking on a frame).
+The example command will create an SVG of 1600 pixels width. + +One of our favorite options is `-s` (or `--simple`) that use simple class names instead of FQDNs, the FlameGraph will be more readable with it, but you will lose the package name.
+You can also limit the profiling duration by using `-d` (or `--duration`) follow by the duration in seconds.

nodes.bodyText:
If you execute ;
$ ./profiler.sh -d 30 <pid>

This is the same as;
$ ./profiler.sh start <pid>
$ sleep 30
$ ./profiler.sh stop <pid>

This will attach the profiler to process <pid>, run for 30s then stop and write the output. A user does not need to execute $ ./profiler.sh start -b <pid> beforehand
Maybe this should be clearer, e.g. "You do not need to explicitly start and stop the profiler."
